--- title: Coracobrachialis Muscle --- :::{layout-ncol="2"} ![Schematic of Pectoralis major and coracobrachialis @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020
1: Pectoralis Major (clavicular part)
2: Pec Major (Sternocostal part)
3: Pec Major (abdominal part)
4: Coracobrachialis](/The Archive/Anatomy/Skeletal Muscles/Upper Limb Muscles/Axioappendicular Anterior Muscles/images/gilroyatlas fig25.25a pectoralis major and coracobrachialis schematic.png) ![Pectoralis Major and Coracobrachialis, anterior view @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020](/The Archive/Anatomy/Skeletal Muscles/Upper Limb Muscles/Axioappendicular Anterior Muscles/images/gilroyatlas fig25.25c pectoralis major and coracobrachialis.png) ::: ::: {#tbl-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Coracobrachialis Coracoid process Humerus (in line with crest of lesser tubercle) Musculocutaneous n.
C5 - C7		 GHJ: Flexion, Adduction, IR
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Coracoid process of [Scapula]({{< var ref-scapula-bone.path >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} Middle 1/3 of [Humerus]({{< var ref-humerus-bone.path >}}) (in line with crest of lesser tubercle) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} [Musculocutaneous N.]({{< var ref-musculocutaneous-nerve.path >}}) ([C5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.c5 >}}), [C6]({{< var ref-nerve-root.c6 >}}), [C7]({{< var ref-nerve-root.c7 >}})) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} **GHJ**: Flexion, Adduction, Internal rotation @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Function Coracobrachialis serves as a secondary flexor and adductor of the shoulder @bielTrailGuideBody2019. # Dysfunction # Pathologies # Palpation The coracobrachialis can be found deep to the [pectoralis major]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.path >}}) and [Anterior Deltoid]({{< var ref-deltoid-muscle-anterior.path >}}). The coracobrachialis is anterior to [Axillary artery]({{< var ref-axillary-artery.path >}}) and [brachial plexus]({{< var ref-brachial-plexus.path >}}), so be mindful when palpating and applying pressure @bielTrailGuideBody2019. ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ### Patient position - Supine @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - 45° GHJ abduction @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - GHJ full external rotation @bielTrailGuideBody2019. ::: ::: {.column} ### Clinician - Locate [pectoralis major]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.path >}}) (anterior wall of the axilla) @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Place one hand on the medial arm, just proximal to the elbow @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Place the fingerpads of the other hand into the axilla @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Instruct the patient to gently adduct into the non-palpating hand @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Palpate the inferior medial edge of the [pectoralis major]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.path >}}), this will act as a reference point @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Dive posterior to pectoralis manjor into the axilla @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - Palpate for the "slender" belly of *coracobrachialis* @bielTrailGuideBody2019. - GHJ adduction should cause it to contract @bielTrailGuideBody2019. ::: ::: ::: {.columns} ::: {.column} ### Checklist - Is the muscle in the medial arm @bielTrailGuideBody2019? - Is it posterior to [pectoralis major]({{< var ref-pectoralis-major.path >}}) @bielTrailGuideBody2019? - Can you strum along the posterior belly @bielTrailGuideBody2019? ::: ::: {.column} ::: ::: # Strength Test # Manual Therapy
